etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Geoffrey Chaucer (c1340–1400), poet and administrator. Originally (in early use) from Middle French agréableté from agréable + -te

definitions: The quality of being agreeable; especially agreeableness of disposition, pleasantness.

notes.text: Before the 18th century apparently only in Chaucer. The word does not appear in any dictionary before Todd's edition of Johnson's Dictionary (1818).
